author: maker_workshop

description.text:
UPDATE: You should really print the improved version of this, it is posted as a remix of this one.  
A bracelet based on Zomboe's chainmail model.  
I really like it, but realized that links in the chainmail could rotate out of place, and make the fabric "buckle". I tried printing two layers, one on top of the other, and it worked great.  
I tweaked the OpenSCAD model to allow for greater clearance in the bridges, so that it doesn't need a lot of rework to make it flexible.  
Finally, I added a clasp mechanism with a couple of little "springs" that help it lock together.  
It should be easy to make this completely customizable in length and width. Anyone up for it?

Make sure your print bed is really level.
Generate the printable file using a 0.27mm layer height. (You can change this in the OpenSCAD file if you need to, but the current STL is optimized for 0.27mm).
The tongue in the clasp mechanism prints with built-in support, so you need to cut it off, and possibly trim the little bumps on the springs.

comments.text: I made one today and it needed some polishing of the lock mechanism, but it works well. Used a Replicator 2 on standard mode.

I like the idea and wanted a remix of a larger version. This allowed me to print 2 layers (at 0.22 layer height) of a solid square and then start on the four tower moving from one to the next. I was able to see ooze and retraction settings along with an issue I was encountering with a jamming filament (for which I ultimately needed a higher temp).
ultimately with MakerGeeks white PLA filament on a Lulzbot Taz 5 had to up the temp to 230C, bed temp of 60C for the first layer than 55C for the remainder.

title: Nixie clock case, 3d printed for In-14 tubes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a 3d printable case for a Nixie clock using IN-14 tubes

This case has been made to fit a Nixie clock QTC kit I purchased from ebay The kit is no longer on ebay but can be found here with the tubes http://www.pvelectronics.co.uk/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=21&products_id=71 I have no connection to the sellers so just for infromation,but I purchased my parts from them and had no problems YMMV.
There are a couple of laser cut cases available but no printed ones so I decided to make one.
I used tinkercad to draw it ,please don't close it down ;(
I have upload a files with all the parts on one table and individual files if you prefer.
I printed my parts one at a time in clear ABS on my reprappro mendel.
I printed at 0.3 layer height with 100% fill as I wanted to see through it. (I may print a lid with hex infill to see how it looks in clear)
I am sure it will print fine at lower fill levels.
the spacers on the lid are quite small and may be the only problem area at a lower fill level.
to assemble I used 4 off M3 nuts which are captive in the feet and 4 M3 x 32mm cap head screws.
the lid just screws straight through the base and into the nuts on the feet.
the board is a tight fit but there is just enough room to line up the LED's and buttons then push it to the bottom.
The tubes I got varied a little in size so i had to clean up the holes a bit to get it all together.
The Nixie board has a socket on the back for a GPS arial/receiver,as I am not using it I did not put a hole in the case for it.If you need it you will need to mod the drawings or drill it in when done.
Not a cheap project but I enjoyed building it from scratch and very happy with the end result.
hope you like it and that someone has a use for it.

author: AnaLuisa21

description.text:
This is a simple rubber band powered torpedo that can be asembled in less than 5 minutes. It can travel 1,5 meters with 300 turns.

More projects here: https://juanggengineering.blogspot.ca

comments.text: These are interesting and a fun engineering challenge. I printed 3. One had a shortened hull to mimic a WWII US MK 13 aerial torpedo. Another one I printed had a regular length hull and was painted up to look like a WWII US MK 14 torpedo. The last one I printed I gave it a 14 cm hull instead of the regular 8 cm hull and printed twin propellers for it. It looks just like a  WWII Japanese type 93 "Long Lance" torpedo. I have yet to find out if doubling up the propellers on the shaft or increasing the hull length and rubber band strength improves performance.
comments.author: TheMadMaker

comments.text: I am happy to hear that you liked this design. I tried to fix one propeller  (mirror of the current one) to the frame and let the other one turn.This way, the body turns in one direction (with one propeller) and the other propeller turns in the other direction achieving somewhat similar to counter rotating propellers. Anyway, in my view you can achieve a maximun of 1,5-2 meters of travel with that system. Publish some photographs of your make if you wish.
comments.author: TheMadMaker

comments.text: does it work
comments.author: EnergyFlurry

comments.text: Well, it depends. It lasts for two seconds - as the torpedo body rotates, so there is the weight in one side and the foam on the other-, resulting in one meter of travel more or less. I am experimenting with electric torpedoes, wich will travel faster and reach longer distances. Try yourself, it is a quick print.
comments.author: EnergyFlurry

comments.text: How are we suppose to put it together
comments.author: con4212

comments.text:
As shown in the photos, glue some wire on the inner side of the tube for balance and some foam on the oposite side.
Then, bend some clips to make the propeller axis and the wire loop on the nose, wich is glued to it t keep it from turning. Propeller axis on the stern should spin freely, you can put a small plastic piece or a whasher to reduce friction.
Note that nose and stern pieces rely on friction to stay toguether with the central section, so if they do not fit properly, scale them a bit up, or down as needed.
If you complete this litle proyect, please post some photos of it.
Thank you for the interest.
I am sorry, I posted this coment six times by accident.

description.text:
HenrySeg builds incredible 3d objects. I found this creation on youtube and he was kind enough to upload it to thingiverse.  
However it was not designed to be printed at home. The files were also not to scale. So I scaled the pieces, broke them down into 3 files: box, box lid, and screw so that it could be printed on a home printer.   
This was printed at .3 layer height, 100% fill, at 100m/s with full supports.  
box top was printed without supports.

title: chillbomb - use the power of wind & water

description.text:
Update 21/07/2015

Makerbot Version (tallest part now < 150mm) available. We've splitted the upper part and did a snap-fit connection. For taller cans and bottles there is also now a part to freely extend your chiller by 50mm for each extenstion element.

Imagine to cool down your drinks only with the power of wind and water. In optimal circumstances you can cool down your drinks for some degrees. We've been inspired by different theories, so you can use this chiller for different uses: Classical use with a wet sock and wind or the freeze option with ice, water and salt. We'll explain shortly all in the description and also put some pictures and movies to this project. Until now there is a version for RedBull cans (250ml, 355ml, 12fl oz) and for LemonSoda. Feel free to scale the parts for your needs :)

We optimised the designed the design to have always enough water, catching the wind as easy as possible and having a cool gadget to take anywhere.

CHILLBOMB - STAY CHILLED!

Printing Info
The parts are optimised to print with a wall thickness of 0.8mm and an infill 20 - 30% depending on slicer.
No supports necessary. Depending on printer a brim for better adhesion is recommended.

If the bottom part tends to leak, just put some glue/silicone in a thin film inside of the part so it will be sealed.
Happy cool printing :)

comments.text: ABS? PLA?
comments.author: good_idea

comments.text: how much water does it use and where does the water go in what part, does anyone know where does the sock go
comments.author: jrscomputer2

comments.text: @jjuasjjuas2: I believe what's happening here is evaporative cooling. The sock acts as an easy-to-source wick that will continue to pull the water from the lower basin as it evaporates from the top. This kind of cooling has been around for a very long time, and is surprisingly efficient! Check out more here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evaporative_cooler

title: Manual wire winch, with planetary multiplier

description.text:
Update 2015-12-07:
I've finally printed this thing and found the design didn't mate as expected.
So I've updated the parts using screws instead of little fragile nails, and added some more play between the gears.
Now the winch works as expected!

The ratio is: (sun_teeth_n+planet_teeth) / (ext_teeth / 2)
in this case: (24 + 18) / (60 / 2) = 36 / 30 = 1.2.
this means that after 1 handle turn, the winch turns 1.2 ruonds.

The 'sun' gear is fixed on the base axis, the handle turn the 3 planets, which multiply the external gear rotation, which is attached to the winch.
It doesn't use any bearing, so maybe the friction will be too much, but with some grease...

I would be glad if someone would like to print it and tell me if it fits and work.

I've added all the single stl files ready to print.
Use all files starting with Pl_ while the file named Planetary3.stl is the old design, which doesn't couple very well..

This was for a class design project. It's a remote that's supposed to be able to control everything, via every signal imaginable: Sound, Light, Various Radio Types, (WiFi, Bluetooth, Cellular, and just plain Radio) Infrared, etc. It can also control things with a hardwire connection via all of those miscellaneous ports you see. The screen is for programming: You can easily customize a different interface for every device which you link to it. You could turn up the volume of your TV, you could play music thru any multimedia system, you could open your garage, or you could put your SmartHouse into "away" mode. These are all examples of the capabilities of my U^2 Remote. It also has connector pins for home programming or further experimentation and customization. (using an Arduino or Raspberry Pi, etc.) Credit to "Gabriel" for his original shape "Rounded," which I used as the base for my U^2 Remote.

Gabriel's Original Shape:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lcgw1CQNLmF-rounded

My U^2 Remote:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kcfMOKe2u5v-u2-remote

title: Filament cooling fan for Overlord 3D Printer

description.text: Some people have issues with the filament getting warmed up by the extruder steppermotor. These 2 parts allow mounting of a 50mm fan in the filament compartment. It will provide some cooling, though i cannot confirm that it will fix this problem because i cannot reproduce it. I used an old 50x50x10 fan, i'm going to try a 15mm one later on.

• Clean up the part a bit after printing, the fan will fit better that way.
  • Mount the fan with 2 fan screws used in personal computers.
  • Prefit the screws that you use to connect the fanholder to the cover.
  • Remove original black cover
  • Insert the fanmount tilted and once straigth, push all the way up
  • Now make sure the wires for the printhead are not stuck on the side
  • Push the fanmount down, making sure the wires can move around freely below the mount.
  • Place the cover in front of the fanmount, align and fit the screws.
    Only for the die hards:
  • Cut a hole in the top of the pillar of the overlord for better airflow......

The last picture shows the opening i made in the top of the OLP. There is nothing structural in that area if you stick to a width of 50mm exactly in the middle. So it can be removed if you work precise. Now all i need to do is make enough holes in the cover.

I think i will order a 24V 50mm fan online so i can connect it to the circuitboard directly.

For now i use an external powersupply, will lookin to that later on.

comments.text: Do the Fan have its own power supply? would really appreciate if instructions are done in steps. Thanks...
comments.author: Ggatch24

comments.text:
@Ggatch24: Try printing it first, you can split the model in cura and print the two parts separately. Maximise picture #3, which shows you the 4 steps. If you cannot figure that out, i think you should not DIY. To protect your brand new printer, i would find someone who can do it for you ;-)
For now i use an external powersupply for the fan until i find a way to connect it to the OLP controllerboard.

Installing O-rings under the keycaps of a mechanical keyboard can help cut down on the loud noise of the key bottoming out.

However if you're not careful to press the O-ring all the way down the shaft it can interfere with typing, causing missed keystrokes or an uneven feel across the keys.

This tool is designed to fit over a 6mm diameter shaft.

description.text: Made these for my Zuul Superbeast but should work on any quad with M3 16x19 motor mounting pattern.

comments.text: Could you make a model of these with a hollow "spike" to save weight? I'm going to try to make it print that way by manipulating the infill, perimeter, and top/bottom layer settings, but I'm not sure it'll work.
comments.author: awptickes

comments.text: Or if you don't have simplify, you could just specify at least 10 solid bottom layers (assuming .2 layer height that should be all of the baseplate). If the rest is going to be hollow I recommend at least 3 perimeter outlines.
comments.author: awptickes

comments.text: You can print it hollow as is, that's what I did. As I mention in the instructions, I recommend printing the baseplate solid and the rest hollow. Depending on your slicer you should be able to specify solid infill up to 2mm height, then hollow after that. Simplify3D will do this if you have it, not sure about the others.

In all the effort to pry parts from the platform, I was reminded of the concern with leaving naked the ABP motor pins on the heater board, so I followed Ed's suggestion here http://softsolder.com/2011/04/15/thing-o-matic-protect-the-abp-motor-terminals-on-an-hbp/ and printed a dummy jumper.

If you print the one hole version you must be careful to check that your print doesn't push the pins together! In order to get a good enough print I had to set Cool>Minimum Layer Time to 5. The openscad file has code for a jumper with two separate holes, but I haven't printed it successfully yet. Update--I'll post the .stl, but expect it to be more difficult to print.
Also, imagine a "dummy jumper" is something way cooler than this.

comments.text: Printed the one with two separate holes... and it worked  8-)

comments.text: Awesome. I started with that but switched to the single hole figuring it would be easier to print, yet I kept changing the code for both. I just tried to print it again and it's better, but by the end of the print the layers are too deformed for the pins to fit.

comments.text: Two holes was my attempt to convey "little divider"... I called it a gap in the code, which is probably the opposite of what it is (relative to positive/negative space). Anyway I don't think anyone would mistake this for a real jumper as is.

author: UAVPilot1

description.text:
Here's a video of it in action...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-4FPl4xUSe8&feature=youtu.be#start=0:00;end=0:15;cycles=-1;autoreplay=true

Here's a group I made for my LED lights and things, if you like my LED designs, join the group and you'll be updated as I upload new ones... I plan on making a lot more logos just like this. So if you have and suggestions, please tell me and I'll make it.

http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/things-with-leds/things

This is a extruded LED Makerbot logo I printed on my dual extruder... I took a JPEG of the Makerbot logo and traced it in Solidworks... I then extruded and filleted the letters and saved them as their own STL to be used in dual extrusion... I then designed a plate around the letters, added holes for screws and save that as its own STL... Lastly, I design a shell to go around the plate and letters, the shell has aligned screw holes so it can be fastened to the plate...

I then printed the shell in regular ole black PLA on my Rep 2... And I did the dual extrusion using the same black PLA for the plate and I used Bendlay (link below) to print the letters... I used Bendlay because it is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)...

I then hooked up an RGB LED strip, wrapped it around the inner shell and hooked it up to an IR receiver so it can be controlled with a remote...

I've also made the following logo's, designs for LED hookup...

SuperMan: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:905146

MakerFaire Robot: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:900647
I <3 3DPing w/beating heart: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:900678

Bendlay Link:
http://www.amazon.com/MatterHackers-BendLay-Filament-1-75mm-MakerBot/dp/B00K1NRCIY/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1435347958&sr=8-1&keywords=bendlay&pebp=1435347954416&perid=1WG2SRVP9TGP9WAM748W

Pretty straight forward, You're going to want to dual extrude the plate and letters together... I used PLA Black for the plate and Bendlay for the letters due to the fact Bendlay is extremely translucent (91% of light passes through)... But you could use Natural PLA or a translucent filament, but they aren't as translucent as Bendlay is...

I did not print a floor on the plate and letters print so it would allow more light to pass through... I did too much infill (10% linear) on mine... I wish I would have done about 5%...

author: ozanbdr

title: Solar Led Light - Tent Light -  - Gardenlight Hack

description.text:
Transform a 1 € / 1$ etc. solar gardenlight into a rechargeable tentlight.
Just print the enclosure, disassamble one ore two gardenlights, add a few leds and you are ready for your next camping trip!

See the instructions for further details.

You have a few choices to build your own tentlight.

Electronics:

The easiest way is to disassamble the gardenlight, desolder the led an add four 3mm leds (parallel circuit)
The outcome is ok, but you can boost the light intensity with just a few modifications.

  1. change the battery. The built-in battery has a low capacity (regardless the capacity printed on the battery). A rechargeable battery between 800mAh and 1350mAh will noticeably increase the time you can youse your light.
  2. Take two gardenlights, and use both circuits with 4 Leds attached to each circuit. One battery and one solarpanel will be enough.
  3. Change the inductor. It looks like a resistor. Use an inductor with 47uH for a higher output. If you don't have one, no problem. You only need some isolated copper wire and the battery-caps. Just coil the wire around the bottom part of the clip. About 60 turns should be enough ( you may test it by connecting the wire to the circuit an alternating the number of turns until the glow of led is at it's maximum)
  4. Add a switch. This way you can switch your light off, without opening your case every time. Just desolder the build in switch and add a bigger one to your case.

I added a small neodym-magnet (round with hole) into each clip and connected a wire to it. You may also use your favorite battery clip from thingiverse.

If you wan't more information about the built-in circuit have a look at: https://ez.analog.com/community/university-program/blog/2014/11/14/hacking-an-led-solar-garden-light

Assembling the housing:

The easiest way to link the lid with the bottom is to cut a m3 thread into the bottom and use small m3 screws. This way you can easily access the electronic compounds.

There are four little holes in the lid. You may add a wire or a string with a carabiner to attach the light to your tent.

comments.text: Thanks for your comment! Alwasy a good idear to re-/upcycle before throwing away :)
comments.author: Connorus

comments.text: Exactly what I was looking for. Our cheap yard lights that we keep with our RV were beat and broken. I've been trying to figure out something to do with them. Who doesn't need this? I'll be sure to post pics when I get one built.

author: keyloop

description.text:
This is a simple organizer I designed to keep my X-Wing tokens organized! I figured since we have a damage deck holder and template holder... why not make a token holder as well!

Included are the STL files so you can out right print it, and the 123d file so you can edit it if you would like.

My printer (M3D Micro) is too small to print this in one go so I halved it and printed it twice and glued it together. The original sketches are still in the 123d file, just extrude them up if you want to print this all in one go.

On my M3D, I used the following settings:

Medium Detail
Medium Infill
No Wave Bonding
Use Raft
Print twice, then remove the rafts. Sand down the connecting edge with a rough grit sandpaper and glue together with hot glue or super glue.

I wanted to have a battery operated 'vintage oil lamp' to take camping. I thought it would look great in a tent, but without the dangers of using a real flame.
I intend to add parts to allow the battery and led's to be fitted.
I've included the drawing files too.
Please note, although I've added lips to allow joining the parts, I've not tested how well fit.
This is to scale, you may have to reduce size to fit on your print bed.

Note this is still in progress, I've yet to print it, although it slices ok with Simplify3d.
Further details when I come to print.
The parts will need rotating to align with your print bed, and most will need support to print well.

After replacing our huge concealed ceiling lights with new super dooper LED down lighters I was left with some nasty looking holes as the new fittings where some 10mm smaller in diameter and a muck mark ring where the ceiling could really have done with a lick of emulsion.

My offering was to to make a couple of old fashioned ceiling roses to hide the holes, to where if I must admit now looks much better than the original fittings....
i found the best results where in ABS printed face down on a Kapton covered glass heat-bed

Joint that fits snugly into 16mm pvc pipes (the stuff used for electrical installations) so that you can join multiple elements to build a circle. We use this as a rig for our circular projection screen.  
The side with the marking has a bit a tighter fit, so when you take it apart one side stays in the pipe.
This is my try for the Make It Float Challenge. The boat is supposed to hold at least two legomen. I haven't tried it yet, though.
Drew an origami-boat in SketchUp, then attached lego-blocks to it. The legoblocks come from the 3D Warehouse.

author: Haywiire

description.text:
This is a back-lit sign that uses "EL-Wire" as the light source.
I had this made on Ponoko.com and it turned out pretty good! :D Materials:
3D Print - Durable Plastic, Black Acrylic, White Acrylic, LiPo Battery, LiPo Charger, EL-Wire (Green) and EL Inverter. You will also need some M3x16mm and M3x30mm bolts. Links:
http://www.ponoko.com/make-and-sell/show-material/237-3d-printed-durable-plastic
http://www.ponoko.com/make-and-sell/show-material/79-acrylic-black
http://www.ponoko.com/make-and-sell/show-material/77-acrylic-white
http://www.ponoko.com/make-and-sell/show-hardware/182-a-polymer-lithium-ion-battery-1000mah
http://www.ponoko.com/make-and-sell/show-hardware/2139-power-cell-lipo-charger-booster
http://www.ponoko.com/make-and-sell/show-hardware/2090-a-el-wire-green-3m
http://www.ponoko.com/make-and-sell/show-hardware/2086-a-el-inverter-3v I've also included the Inventor File, if you want to mess with it.

Hot-Glue the black acrylic to the printed parts.
Run/thread the el-wire in and out thru/around the printed parts and the acrylic panel. Use the M3 bolts to fasten the printed parts to the acrylic.
I put a switch in line with my power supply to make it easy to turn on and off.
Pretty much straight forward on what goes where.
FYI: The current plans don't accommodate the power inverter. So you will need to adjust for that.. I just let the electronics stay on the outside. I will probably get around to actually mounting them some time... :P

Modified iconic lizard by M. C. Escher in 3 dimensions.  The top is drafted at 60Â° to create artistic striations of the profile when printed with a standard .010 inch per layer FDM printer.  The individual pieces interconnect on a 1 inch hexagonal pattern.  I find this to be a good example of the accuracy and ressolution of these printers.  The parts are line to line and snap together nicely.  X and Y coordinates show the limit of resolution and the Z coordinate shows the comparative  coarseness of detail in that axis.

I pasted and scaled a jpg  and traced the Escher Lizard in SolidWorks over a 1" Hex.  Then I deleted the lines that were rotations of the profile.  I then rotated the profile 120Â° on the appropriate verticies of the hex.  I extruded once straight and again with draft.  The image needed a bit of adjusting to create common planes and a bit of symetry for the head.

comments.text: I made several of these and they fit together reasonably well, it requires trimming the base layer flashing with an X-ACTO knife because the first print layer is generally wider than the model size, after that the following layers are to the model size. The clean-up, generally takes as long as the print (at least at first). Look at the base layer with a magnifying glass to see what I am talking about. I use a over head magnifier to trim and clean up parts.
comments.author: ultiPop

comments.text: The file seems not to be an stl file. It is probably some proprietary format from SolidWorks as the first bytes of the binary files reads "solid Escher Lizard PMM".

comments.author: misty_soul

comments.text: No, the file doesn't print. It is really a binary file whereas STL files are text based. Renaming is probably not sufficient, the content should be changed. Some web search suggest that SolidWroks (at least student version, I don't know if it is the one you use) cannot export as STL. Too bad :-(
comments.author: Cluelessdweeb

comments.text: I just down loaded this file from this site and opened it flawlessly with my Dimension printer software (CatalystEX).  It would seem that you may be the one with file limitations on your software.  What are you using?
comments.author: misty_soul

comments.text: STL is a standardized format that pretty much all 3D printers and 3D design software can work with.  What you've uploaded is something proprietary to your CatalystEX software, that can't be read by anything else, and renaming it doesn't fix that.  What misty_soul is asking, and I concur, is if you can produce an actual STL file and upload that here, so everyone can use your lovely design, rather than just people who use the specific equipment and software you're using.  Unfortunately, a Google search didn't turn up anything about how to export to the standard STL format from your CatalystEX software, so it may be that it can only import but not export this universal format.  If so, that's a damned shame -- hardly anyone can use your design.
comments.author: Cluelessdweeb

The STLs that I create from SolidWorks (and I have done many) print on my printer and every other commercial printer that I have sent them to.  Can you print this file?  This is the first file I have sent to Thigiverse and if there are problems printing it, I suspect that there may be issues with the upload process.            Who else out there is having trouble?

author: verndawg

description.text:
Forelimb prosthetics for medium and small pets is a one piece, very light weight, comfortable, articulated and low cost aid for those pets that unfortunately had lost part of their front legs.

The design is super-simple and it works perfectly (watch video).

The piece must be printed in Nylon to achieve both resistance and flexibility.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x8yj_-ga4yg

A Sketchup skp source file is included if you like to adapt it to a particular pet. Also, you can customize size for the different parts of the prosthetics directly from the slicer program (see instructions).

Nylon provides both resistance and flexibility. Print using 0.2mm slices and 40% infill. It prints without support.

To facilitate customization, three different stl files are included: The PAW replaces de missing part of the leg, the SHOE is where it is secured to the stump and the ARTICULATION wraps around the elbow and the forearm. Each of the pieces can be resized directly in the slicer program to fit the pet's measurements. After resizing, is important that the three pieces are aligned together perfectly so they can be printed as a single piece.

comments.text: This is great! I have a pup with a short front leg and that is why I bought the printer! this is exactly what I want to do! thanks, this is such a great story!
comments.author: Jenniferk

comments.text: Thanks for your comment. Pelase don't hesitate to contact me if you have any question. I will be glad to help in anyway.

comments.text: Awesome! Good to know I can make this if I ever know a furry friend in need!

description.text:
This iPhone 5 holder holds your phone securely on any standard 1/4"-20 mount (standard camera mount). EcoXGear makes a handlebar mount and a suction cup mount that lets you mount your iPhone 5 securely and adjust the angle. You can get them at West Marine and lots of other places for about $12. I have one for my bike handlebar so I can play Bluetooth music and use Google maps, and another for my dash on my speedboat so I can use my iPhone navigation system.

Print the Thing. Remove the tabs marked REMOVE (that piece just helps stick your Thing to the build plate and holds up the overhang for the charge port so you don't need to use support structures). Buy a 1/4"-20 T-nut from your hardware store (see the picture of one - they're about 10 cents). Stick it down the throat of the holder and then glue the little dime sized disk that prints with it into the throat to hold the T-nut securely in place. Screw the mount into the T-nut and you've got a super secure, versatile iPhone holder.

Print the Thing. Remove the tabs marked REMOVE (that piece just helps stick your Thing to the build plate and holds up the overhang for the charge port so you don't need to use support structures). Buy a 1/4"-20 T-nut from your hardware store (see the picture of one - they're about 10 cents). Stick it down the throat of the holder and then glue the little dime sized disk that prints with it into the throat to hold the T-nut securely in place. Screw the mount into the T-nut and you've got a super secure, versatile iPhone holder.

Need a place to hold your test leads?

The spaces are 5mm apart, and I'll probably create more variations on this where they are farther apart for different sized cords.

Very simple and not terribly elegant!

This is a GT2 2mm belt profile made into a rack. Could be used for the drive of a 3D printer or light-duty CNC machine. I verified it fits an actual belt perfectly. The rack is 6mm wide, so it will fit down the middle of typical 20x rails. It's also designed so that you can lay individual pieces end-to-end, and the belt will still mesh properly, within printer tolerances of course.
I printed it with no support at 25% fill on a Flashforge Creator X (or the Monoprice clone therof.)

Alligator Clip Leads are something I use quite often to jump wires and components from one prototyping project to the next, and they are a pain in the ass to organize.

For a few weeks now I have been using a piece of 1/16" craft foam duct-taped to the bottom of one of my drawer boxes to hold the clip leads. I really like this method as it organizes and cleanly displays the leads for easy access. Unfortunately this mounting method is flawed in that the duct tape does not like to stick to anything for long in an air-conditioned environment due to the air-conditioning system pulling all of the moisture out of the air.

I designed this part to be 3D printed and mounted to any over-hanging surface with a minimum width of 30mm. When mounted with 3M foam mounting tape, it will stick forever and has enough room for about 25-30 clip leads.

I have included the sketchup file if you want to modify this to suit your needs. If you modify please re-upload and mark as a derivative of this project. Also if you make one, list it as a make! I love seeing other people print my designs!

Print with a layer height of between .2 and .3 using 30% infill. A brim of 8-10mm helps with warping when using ABS.

Mount to an overhanging surface like the bottom of a shelf. The part is 180mm long by 30mm wide. Mount using 3M double-sided foam mounting tape.

I have included the sketchup file if you want to modify this to suit your needs. If you modify please re-upload and mark as a derivative of this project. Also if you make one, list it as a make! I love seeing other people print my designs!

description.text:
This is a two part cityscape ring. I usually cut them in acrylic, but they also look badass in wood.
The file here is a size 7 ring, but its easy to swap out the inside circles. Once you get up to about 8.5 you may run into trouble with the walls being too thin, widening the design should fix that.

Step 1, FIRE THE LASER (vector cut)
Step 2, enjoy! You are welcome to make one of these for yourself or a friend, but please don't sell them.
If you'd like a ring of your own, you can order one from my Etsy shop, http://kfarrell.etsy.com . And buying a ring supports me so I can make more designs to upload. It's a wonderful cycle.

Designed by Grade 12 student, Justin A.  It is meant to be a fun way to sort your canadian change (Twonies, Loonies, Quarters, Dimes, and Nickels).

PLA gave us the best results. ABS cracked and warped on our makerbot. It took a very very very long time to print. Thank goodness Makerbots now have a "cold pause". PLA
.2 layer height
15% infill
2 shells
Nozzle Temp 190
Bed Temp 0 The top piece is the most important (MoneySlider1.stl) because it is the actual slider. There are two bases to choose from. Justin has only tried the first base (MoneySlider2.stl). He has not tried the additional base that would result in stacks of coins (MoneySlider3.stl). It was the teacher's idea and even she is skeptical about whether it would actually work. ...and these parts took a long time to print and other students were waiting to have their designs printed. NOTE: This design was our 3rd printing of the top portion. The Twonies stil get hung up on the loonie slot despite revisions to the design. The quarters, nickels, and dimes work great. Even though it doesn't work perfectly, we thought we'd upload it and see who might accept the challenge of revising it.

description.text: small spotlight made from a nine led flashlight. i am 15 so any design pointers are welcome. this was designed in freecad (http://www.freecadweb.org/)

supply's:
9 led flashlight (http://www.harborfreight.com/3-12-in-9-led-mini-flashlight-69052.html
hot glue gun
soldering iron
wire
5 volt power supply or usb cable
tape

step 1 pry the glass of the front of the flashlight and remove the led pcb

step 2 remove the rubber casing from the back of the flashlight and remove the button

step 3 solder the positive wire of your supply cable to the positive lead of one of the leds (the smaller piece of metal). then solder a short wire to one of the negative lead of one of the leds and then to one side of the switch

step 4 solder the negative wire on the supply cable to the other side of the switch

step 5 glue the switch in the case with hot glue

step 6 put some hot glue on the terminals of the switch to prevent it from shorting out

step 7 as GeekDad63 suggested put some tape on the inside to contain the light

step 8 press the led pcb into the led spacer

step 9 put the led spacer in the case

step 10 put some hot glue in the cups of the turntable to hold it steady

step 11 glue the cable in place

remixed_from.author: Parkinbot
remixed_from.title: NACA Airfoils - 4 digit fully parametric OpenSCAD library

description.text:
June, 30 - updated Naca_sweep.scad and Naca4.scad

The STL designs shown along with this thing are not really meant for printing, rather to visually demonstrate the power of a special programming technique based on new features of OpenSCAD 2015 that will allow you to do really wicked stuff. Also I verify a promise given in a previous post NACA Airfoils - 4 digit fully parametric OpenSCAD library, where I introduced some very flexible airfoil calculation functionality.

To give you an overview where this programming technique applies: As long as a wing, fin, blade or fuselage design does not exceed the (scalable) range of a single NACA airfoil type almost all requirements will be accomplished by juggling around with the mighty OpenSCAD operators linear_extrude() and rotate_extrude().

Whenever a specific (e.g. non-linear) trajectory and/or a transition between different airfoil types, say between a NACA1480 and a NACA1510 is demanded, one is stumped with this tools. In cases, where convexity is granted for all shapes, the hull() operator maybe helpful. I have demonstrated this technique in my Springs, helicoils, elliptic rings post. Concave stuff by contrast is always more resistive.

With this post I show the implementation of a sweep operator that connects a set of 2D "slices" placed on a trajectory in 3D space into a single polyhedron. Each slice must be derived from a non-self-intersecting polygon describing a 2D shape, like an airfoil (or any other shape) and have the same number of points as all others. Transformed into a 3D point set, Euclidean transformations are applied to correctly place it on the trajectory in 3D space sweep() builds an object of.

My two examples present two techniques to generate trajectory hull objects with transitions:

  1. Slice objects built of two (or more) 2D shapes and composed by union(). This approach is easier, but CGAL (F6) rendering can take a lot of time.
  2. Polyhedron objects built from a vector of 2D shapes. This approach needs a function to generate the vector set and has the advantage of CGAL rendering being very fast.

The code for central module sweep(dat, convexity){ } is just a few lines. You call it with a fully prepared vector of 3D points set vectors.

To be be able to freely place a 2D shape within 3D space, I added a bunch of functions operating over points sets and providing translation, rotation and scaling functionality.

Use functions

  • v3D to expand a 2D point set vector [[X1, Y1], ... , [Xn, Yn]] into the 3D point set vector [[X1, Y1, 0], ... , [Xn, Yn, 0]]
  • T_(x=0, y=0, z=0, v) to translate a point set vector v in all three dimensions.
  • R_(x=0, y=0, z=0, v) to rotate a point set vector v in all three dimensions.
  • S_(x=1, y=1, z=1, v) to scale a point set vector v in all three dimensions.
  • Tx(x=0, v), Ty(y=0, v), Tz_(z=0, v) as shortcuts to translate a point set vector v in one dimension.
  • Rx(x=0, v), Ry(y=0, v), Rz_(z=0, v) as shortcuts to rotate a point set vector v in one dimension.
  • Sx(x=1, v), Sy(y=1, v), Sz_(z=1, v) as shortcuts to scale a point set vector v in one dimension.

A last hint: Use F12 to check whether triangle orientation in the polyhedron is correct and has no self-intersections. If you see any purple triangles after F5, there is a problem and the result will be rejected by CGAL or at least cause trouble when applying any Boolean operations.
If everything is purple, you can either

  • reverse your tracjectory by changing the sign of the path variable.
  • or reverse the vertex order in all your polygons

Have fun!

This opener was specifically dimensioned to hug the bottle for a longer lasting and better functioning opener.

I wanted to print my own bottle opener but nearly all of the existing designs either use a coin or are of a flat like design. The flat design causes a stress increase at the point of opening that can be relieved by a curved design that covers more of the bottle cap and hugs the bottle.

I tested it printing 5 perimeters with 50% honeycomb infill using ABS and I'm very happy with it.
